content: * *Wee Ah Hood** ([Simplified Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese): 黄亚佛; [Traditional Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese): 黃亞佛) (1828–1875) was a prominent pepper and [gambier](/wiki/Uncaria_gambir) plantation owner in the [Colony of Singapore](/wiki/Colony_of_Singapore). He lived in the House of Wee Ah Hood, which was one of [four well-known Chinese-style mansions in Singapore](/wiki/Four_Mansions). ## Biography Wee was born on Circular Road in 1828 to [Teochew](/wiki/Teochew_people) trader Wee Ah Heng, who died when Wee was six months old. He was initially an assistant in a cloth-dealer's shop, and later became the manager. Following the retirement of his boss, he established his own business, Ah Hood & Co., which included various types of products. The business was very successful, making him one of the largest pepper and [gambier](/wiki/Uncaria_gambir) merchants during his time. His eldest son, Wee Kim Yan, was born in 1855. Wee died in 1875 in his residence. The House of Wee Ah Hood, which was commonly regarded as one of [four well-known Chinese-style mansions in Singapore](/wiki/Four_Mansions), was constructed in 1878 on 49 [Hill Street](/wiki/Hill_Street,_Singapore). Ah Hood Road was named after him. This Singapore-related article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: Wee Ah Hood
